title-group.article-title: Autoproteolysis of Procerain and Procerain B mediated by structural changes

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: Autoproteolysis of Procerain and Procerain B mediated by structural changes

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p:
Gaurav Srivastava a , Neeraj Gaur b , Ravindra D. Makde b , Sahayog N. Jamdar
a, *

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p:
a
Food Technology Division, Bhabha Atomic Research Centre, Mumbai , India b Beamline Development &
Application Section, Bhabha Atomic Research Centre, Mumbai , India

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: A R T I C L E I N F O

sec.title: Keywords:
sec.p: Procerain
Procerain B
Autolysis
Proteases
Structural stability
DSF
A B S T R A C T

Procerain (Pc) and Procerain B (PcB) are two latex proteases from
Calotropis procera
having potential applications in food and other industries. However, autolytic degradation of these proteases limits their potential use in industry. Nevertheless, basic mechanism underlying the autoproteolysis has not been detailed. In order to understand the same, we subjected the enzymes to various denaturing and activating conditions. The results showed that structural changes induced by different denaturing conditions trigger their autoproteolysis. We also observed differential response of Pc, PcB and other papain-like proteases towards autocatalysis in presence of reducing agent in-spite of sharing the same structural fold, including the number of disulfide bonds. The possible reason underlying this intriguing observation is also discussed. Further, present work establishes that structural changes in the proteases lead to autoproteolysis and the enzymes are stable unless they experience structural perturbation. These findings could thus be useful for their practical applications in industries.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p:
In order to study the stability of these proteases, the purification was carried out in the absence of inhibitor and purified protein was subjected to SDS-PAGE to check the purity of the preparation. Surprisingly, the polypeptide band did not appear on the gel or it was very faint even after loading sufficiently high amount of the purified proteins. This phenomenon was observed for both Pc and PcB. Addition of sodium tetrathionate to the enzyme before subjecting to electrophoresis also yielded similar results. However, addition of E-64, an irreversible inhibitor of cysteine proteases (
) prior to sample preparation for SDS-PAGE was effective to observe the protein bands on the gel. It thus indicated that both the enzymes might be proteolytically active and undergo autolysis during boiling with sample buffer containing 2% SDS and 150 mM β- ME. Hence, the kinetic stability of the enzymes at different temperatures was studied in presence of denaturants/activators like SDS, β- ME and GdnHCl. The main focus of the study is to see the effect of temperature on denaturation vis a vis autodegradation of the enzymes in presence of these agents. Further, it would be interesting to elucidate the mechanism by which the proteases undergo self-degradation in these different environments.

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: * Corresponding author.

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: E-mail addresses: snjam@barc.gov.in, snjam2@gmail.com (S.N. Jamdar).

sec.title: 2.1. Purification of Pc and PcB and their SDS-PAGE profile
sec.p:
Pc and PcB were purified according to the method described by (
) and (Singh et al., 2010), respectively, with minor modifications. The purification was carried out at 4 ◦ C in the absence of any inhibitor. The final purification of both enzymes was carried out on Superdex 200 to obtain their single symmetrical peaks. The purified enzymes were subsequently used for all the experiments described here.

sec.title: 2.2. Kinetic stability of Pc and PcB
2.2.1. Enzyme activity
sec.p:
Kinetic stability of the enzymes at different temperatures was monitored by measuring their residual activities upon incubation in the conditions where autodigestion was observed ( Fig. 2A and B ). For native enzymes, temperature stability was monitored in absence or presence of reducing agent (1–150 mM β- ME) by incubating at different temperatures for 10 min. The residual activity of Pc and PcB is shown in Fig. 2A and B , respectively. The result shows that Pc is rather stable up to 70 ◦ C and showed gradual decrease in activity thereafter. Similar observations had been made in previous studies (
). The relative stability of PcB is lower than that of Pc, with the former showing steady decrease in activity as the temperature increased from 30 ◦ C to 85 ◦ C. The presence of β- ME did not affect the stability of both the enzymes at lower temperatures at least for 10 min, however, as the temperature increased, higher concentrations of β- ME led to decrease in the activity. On the other hand, lower concentrations (1 and 10 mM) of β- ME actually exhibited activation of PcB in the temperature range of 50–70 ◦ C.

Stability of the enzymes in SDS (2%) alone and in combination with β- ME (150 mM) was assessed at ambient conditions and 50 ◦ C for 3 min ( Fig. 2C and D ). At ambient conditions, Pc retained 25% residual activity in both 2% SDS as well as 2% SDS containing 150 mM β- ME, while at 50 ◦ C, it showed complete loss of activity in both the conditions. PcB on the other hand showed complete inactivation even at ambient conditions. Stability of the enzymes was also studied in presence of GdnHCl in the range of 2–4 M concentration, either alone or in combination with β- ME (150 mM) at ambient conditions, 50 ◦ C and 65 ◦ C for 3 min ( Fig. 2E and F ). At ambient conditions, both the enzymes did not show significant loss in activity even at 4 M concentration of GdnHCl. Previous studies had reported that Pc and PcB are stable in 4 M and 2 M GdnHCl, respectively, at ambient conditions (
; Singh et al., 2010), while our observations show that PcB is also stable even up to 4 M GdnHCl. At 50 ◦ C, PcB, but not Pc, showed steady loss in activity at 3 M and 4 M concentration of GdnHCl. At 65 ◦ C, Pc showed 35% loss in activity at 3 M concentration, while > 90% loss was observed at 4 M concentration. PcB, at this temperature, showed 70% reduction in activity with 2 M GdnHCl, while > 90% loss was observed at 3 M and 4 M concentrations. No additional loss of enzyme activity was observed when the combination of β- ME and GdnHCl was used at ambient conditions and 50 ◦ C, however, at 65 ◦ C, it showed significant reduction in activity, which is similar to that observed with β- ME alone ( Fig. 2E and F ).

sec.title: 2.2.2. Protein denaturation kinetics
2.3. Autodigestion of Pc and PcB at different temperatures in presence of
2.3.1. SDS sample buffer components
sec.p: Autodigestion of Pc and PcB in sample buffer and its individual components was monitored at different temperatures. The protein was subjected to individual conditions for 3 min in a similar way as carried out for SDS-PAGE sample preparation. After the incubation time, the reaction tube was quickly transferred to ice bath and 0.1 mM of E-64 was added to stop possible autodigestion during sample preparation and subjected to SDS-PAGE. The results are presented in Fig. 4 (A-G). The figures show that Pc and PcB exhibited autodigestion at different temperatures depending on the presence of a particular component of the sample buffer. In native conditions, i.e., 50 mM phosphate buffer pH 7.0, both Pc and PcB were observed to be stable to proteolysis by itself up to 80 ◦ C, however, at 85 ◦ C, they undergo autodigestion. Intriguingly, autodigestion of Pc was observed even at 100 ◦ C, while not for PcB. This could be due to rapid loss of activity of PcB at boiling temperature, thereby preventing its complete autodigestion. In 2% SDS, complete autodigestion of Pc and PcB was observed at 50 ◦ C and 37 ◦ C, respectively, after 3 min. However, at temperature ≥70 ◦ C, the autodigestibility of Pc was slightly reduced and protein band started to appear on the gel ( Fig. 4D–G ). This could be due to higher rate of inactivation at these temperatures leading to diminished autodigestion. For PcB, autodigestion in presence of 2% SDS was observed even at higher temperatures ( > 70 ◦ C). Autoproteolysis in presence of 150 mM β- ME, for both the enzymes, was discernible at temperatures ≥70 ◦ C and could be observed even up to 100 ◦ C. Autodegradation profile of the enzymes in presence of 2% SDS and 150 mM β- ME combination is just similar to that observed for individual enzymes in presence of 2% SDS alone except for PcB at temperatures above 70 ◦ C. In the latter conditions, unlike Pc, PcB showed complete autodigestion.

sec.title: 2.3.2. GdnHCl and GdnHCl in combination with β- ME
sec.p: The autodigestion of the Pc and PcB was also evaluated in the presence of different concentrations of GdnHCl (2–4 M) ( Fig. 5A–F ). Results showed that Pc is stable towards denaturation by GdnHCl (up to 4 M) till 50 ◦ C, either alone or in combination with β- ME (150 mM). However, autodigestion in presence of GdnHCl was evident at 65 ◦ C in concentration dependent manner and was more pronounced in combination with β- ME. Similar effect was also observed with PcB, although at lower temperature (50 ◦ C) and without much observable influence of the presence of β- ME.

sec.title: 2.4. Kinetic stability of different proteases of C1 family in presence of
sec.p: β- ME

Kinetic stability of four C1 family proteases viz . Pc, PcB, bromelain and papain ( Fig. 6 ) was studied in the presence of different concentrations of β- ME at 50 ◦ C up to 2 h. Bromelain was found to be the most susceptible for inactivation in presence of higher concentration of β- ME (100 mM) showing loss of nearly 80% activity at the end of 1 h incubation. In the similar conditions, PcB showed 25 and 41% loss in the activity after 1 and 2 h of incubation, respectively. Pc, on the other hand was quite resistant to get inactivated and showed just 12% and 16% loss of activity at the end of 1 and 2 h of incubation in presence of 200 mM β- ME, respectively. Papain showed the highest resistance towards inactivation by β- ME; it shows less than 5% loss of activity even in the presence of 400 mM of β- ME at the end of 2 h of incubation.

In order to check, if the inactivation also leads to autoproteolysis of the enzymes, SDS-PAGE profile of the proteins was observed at the end of incubation period ( Fig. 6E and F ). The autoproteolysis was mainly observed for bromelain and PcB incubated in the presence of 100 mM β- ME at 50 ◦ C for 1 h and 2 h, respectively. Papain did not exhibit any major changes in the band intensity, while Pc showed marginal change in the band intensity upon incubation in presence of 100 and 200 mM β- ME concentrations.

sec.title: 2.5. Evaluating effect of disulphide bonds on the autolysis of PcB by homology modelling and molecular dynamics simulations
3. Discussion
sec.p:
Our initial observations regarding the SDS-PAGE profiles of Pc and PcB were quite surprising as the protein bands corresponding to full-length protein were not visible despite high amounts of loading (up to 20 μg) on the gel. Moreover, proteins purified in the presence of reversible inhibitor, sodium tetrathionate also showed the same behaviour. Appearance of full-length protein bands, however, could only be observed after addition of E-64 (an irreversible cysteine protease inhibitor) during SDS-PAGE sample preparation. These preliminary observations suggested that the proteins were catalytically active in the denaturing conditions during SDS-PAGE sample preparation and thus possibly undergoing autolytic cleavage resulting in the absence of full-length protein bands on the gel. Such autolytic degradation has been reported previously for ‘cholesterol-binding pancreatic proteinase’ in presence of SDS and evidenced by disappearance of the polypeptide band on the gel by
. The author postulated partial unfolding of the protein to be the cause of this autodigestion. However, this phenomenon of autolytic digestion during SDS-PAGE sample preparation for Pc and PcB or other cysteine proteases has not been reported earlier. Although both Pc and PcB proteins were studied for their stability in different physical and chemical conditions, the proteins used were inhibited with sodium tetrathionate to prevent autodigestion (
; Singh et al., 2010). Stability studies revealed high stability of both the enzymes to wide range of pH and temperature conditions as well as to chemical denaturants like urea, GdnHCl or SDS. In fact, these enzymes are reported to be highly stable even at those temperatures where it possesses optimum activities (50–70 ◦ C). On the contrary, presence of activator like β- ME has been stated to cause autodigestion of these enzymes even at 37 ◦ C where both the enzymes are otherwise shown to be very stable in the absence of β- ME (
; Singh et al., 2010). Thus, it indicates mere activation of the enzymes can lead to their self-cleavage at relatively lower temperature. This paradox has not been discussed in any of the previous reports and it thus felt necessary to establish the cause and conditions of autolytic degradation of these proteases. In order to ascertain whether it is the denaturation or activation of the enzymes, which causes autolysis, we examined the stability of the enzymes at different temperatures in presence of denaturants (SDS and GdnHCl) and activator (β- ME). The kinetic stability of the enzymes was evaluated in terms of enzymatic activities and SDS-PAGE profiles to assess the loss in catalytic activity and autocatalysis, respectively. We also used DSF to study conformational stability of the enzymes in real time.

In order to determine the minimum temperature at which enzymes rapidly lose their activity, individual enzymes were incubated in presence or absence of denaturants and/or activators at different temperatures. The residual activities were measured and are depicted in Fig. 2 . Native Pc showed rapid loss of activity at temperature ≥75 ◦ C, while PcB showed steady decline in activity from 50 ◦ C onward with ≥85% loss of activity at 80 ◦ C after 10 min of incubation. However, the presence of higher concentration (≥50 mM) of β- ME resulted in greater loss of activity for both the enzymes at relatively lower temperatures (65 ◦ C) compared to the enzymes incubated in 0, 1 or 10 mM β- ME. In fact, the lower concentrations of β- ME (1, 10 mM) exhibited activation for both the enzymes in the entire range of temperature studied.

The stability studies carried out in the presence of denaturing agent, SDS (2%), showed complete loss of activity at 30 ◦ C and 50 ◦ C for PcB and Pc, respectively ( Fig. 2C and D ). In presence of GdnHCl (4 M), ≥70% inactivation was observed for PcB, but not for Pc even at 50 ◦ C ( Fig. 2E and F ). The latter got inactivated only at 65 ◦ C. In above conditions, presence of β- ME did not have any additional effect on inactivation of the enzymes by either SDS or GdnHCl. The substantial loss of activity observed in presence of 2–4 M GdnHCl in combination with β- ME and at higher temperature (65 ◦ C), especially in case of Pc, is primarily due to presence of β- ME itself.

Overall, the results obtained with enzyme inactivation studies corroborate the findings of DSF experiments carried out to monitor the conformational changes in the protein. For instance, the melting or denaturation started at temperatures ≥75 ◦ C for both the enzymes, which may be the cause of drastic decrease in the activities of the enzymes above this temperature. The presence of β- ME resulted in slight decrease in the denaturation temperature for Pc and PcB, with the effect more pronounced in case of Pc. However, the enzyme assay studies showed inactivation of PcB at much lower temperature in presence of 150 mM β- ME. This could be because the residual activities were estimated after 10 min of incubation at respective temperatures while in DSF studies the enzyme encountered 5 s at each temperature. The DSF studies also provided information on melting of PcB in the presence GdnHCl, however, the same could not be obtained for Pc because we could not observe any increase in fluorescence in the entire range of temperature. Nevertheless, PcB showed lowering of denaturation temperature in the presence of GdnHCl in a concentration dependent manner which is in agreement with the enzyme activity measurement studies.

In view of all the aforementioned results, it is quite clear that activation or denaturation of Pc and PcB is differentially affected by β- ME, SDS or GdnHCl and Pc is relatively more stable than PcB towards the denaturation by these agents. This is in agreement with previous studies by (
; Singh et al., 2010) where it was reported that Pc has higher stability towards temperature and reducing agent than PcB. Thus, it was interesting to check how these two proteins respond to these denaturing or activating conditions in terms of their autodigestion. In order to assess the autocatalysis of the enzymes subjected to these conditions, protein profiles were observed by SDS-PAGE immediately after subjecting to these conditions and inhibiting any residual activity of the enzymes by E-64. The results showed that all those conditions in which denaturation and significant decline in activities were observed, showed autodegradation as well. For instance, the lowest temperature at which Pc and PcB showed complete loss of activity in presence of 2% SDS were 50 ◦ C and 37 ◦ C, respectively. The very conditions also showed near complete degradation of the enzymes on SDS-PAGE as well. Moreover, the proteins showed degradation above 80 ◦ C, where rapid decline in activity and global unfolding were also observed. The collective evidence also confirmed that the loss of activity in presence of 150 mM β- ME, but not that of native protein, at temperatures near 70 ◦ C is due to denaturation and subsequently autodegradation of the enzymes. Higher concentration of β- ME (150 mM) facilitates denaturation of the enzymes at higher temperature which could be attributed to the reduction of disulphide bonds, in turn leading to their autodegradation. It is thus possible that higher concentrations of β- ME might cause denaturation of the enzymes in similar manner at lower temperatures, if incubated for longer time. On the contrary, at lower concentrations (1–10 mM) of β- ME, enhanced activity of the enzymes was observed at all the temperatures. This suggests that activation by β- ME per se would not lead to autodegradation. Thus the autolytic degradation of the enzyme is not due to activation of the enzyme in presence of β- ME as reported byprevious studies (
; Singh et al., 2010), but due to conformational changes brought about by higher concentrations of reducing agent as the activation could only be observedat lower concentration of β- ME, which does not cause autolysis of enzymes. It was confirmed by SDS-PAGE profiles of both the enzymes after incubating for prolonged time (up to 5 h) in lower ( < 10 mM) concentration of β- ME (data not shown). The present studies thus confirm that both the proteins undergo autolysis in those conditions where conformational changes in their structures are observed. Secondly, the rate of autocatalysis was always higher than their denaturation rate even at boiling temperatures in presence of 2% SDS and/or 150 mM β- ME.

sec.title: 4. Conclusion
sec.p: Procerain and Procerain B undergo rapid and extensive autocatalysis under highly denaturing conditions like those encountered during sample preparation for SDS-PAGE. The autoproteolysis of the enzymes is initiated once they encounter denaturing conditions. The phenomenon thus suggests that rate of autocatalysis is higher than that of denaturation. Autoproteolysis is also observed in other papain-like cysteine proteases from C1 family, however, the conditions in which the phenomenon is observed varies for individual enzymes. Concentration of reducing agent is one of the major factors that governs autocatalysis near their optimum temperatures and thus has to be taken into consideration while selecting particular enzyme from C1 family for their industrial applications.

sec.title: 5. Experimental
5.1. Purification of Pc and PcB
sec.p: All the procedure involving purification were carried out at 4 ◦ C unless it is stated.

The latex of
Calotropis procera
(family Asclepiadaceae ) was obtained from the plant stem in 25 mM phosphate buffer pH 7.0 in cold. It was mixed thoroughly and centrifuged at 30,000× g for 40 min. The supernatant was then subjected to ion exchange chromatography on CM-Sepharose Fast flow, pre-equilibrated with 25 mM phosphate buffer pH 7.0. The adsorbed protein was eluted with gradient (0–0.8 M) of NaCl prepared in equilibrating buffer. The proteins eluted as two major peaks as observed using A 280nm ,
pooled separately, concentrated by ultrafiltration and then individually subjected to gel filtration chromatography. The Superdex 200 10/ 300 mm (Cytiva, US ), connected to a Quaternary pump (Jasco, PU2089 plus, Japan ) was pre-equilibrated with 25 mM phosphate buffer pH 7.0 containing 150 mM NaCl. It was also calibrated with gel filtration standards (Sigma, USA ) viz . β- amylase (200 kDa), alcohol dehydrogenase (150 kDa), bovine serum albumin (66 kDa), carbonic anhydrase (29 kDa), cytochrome C (12.4 kDa) and blue dextran (2000 kDa). The proteins, Pc and PcB, eluted at molecular weight of 29 kDa and 24 kDa, respectively, were then collected and used for all the further studies. The calibration curve of Log molecular weight vs V /
Vo
was plotted, where V represents elution volume of the protein and
Vo
is the void volume of the gel filtration column. The protein concentration was determined with the Bradford assay method (
).

sec.title: 5.2. SDS-PAGE
5.3. Enzyme assay
sec.p:
The activity of both the enzymes was assessed using azocasein as substrate and in 50 mM phosphate buffer pH 7.0 and at 50 ◦ C. The assay mixture consisted of 5 μg of the enzyme, 125 μL of buffer and 125 μL of 3% azocasein prepared in the assay buffer. The mixture was incubated for 10 min at 50 ◦ C and then added 250 μL of 10% ice-cold TCA to terminate the reaction. The TCA soluble products obtained after centrifuging the assay mixture was read at 366 nm . One unit of the enzyme was considered as Δ
A
366nm
= 0.001.

sec.title: 5.4. Protein stability studies
sec.p: Stability of the enzymes Pc and PcB was assessed in terms of enzyme activities, autocatalysis and conformational changes in presence of different denaturants (SDS/GdnHCl) or activators (β- ME).

sec.title: 5.4.1. Native enzymes and in presence of β- ME (1–150 mM)
sec.p: For stability studies of the native enzymes in the presence and absence of β- ME (1–150 mM), the enzymes (5 μg) were incubated in 125 μL of 50 mM phosphate buffer pH 7.0 at different temperatures viz . 4 ◦ C, 30 ◦ C, 50 ◦ C, 60 ◦ C, 65 ◦ C, 70 ◦ C, 75 ◦ C, 80 ◦ C and 85 ◦ C for 10 min. The residual activities of the enzymes were estimated by assaying the enzymes using azocasein as substrate as explained earlier.

sec.title: 5.4.2. In presence of SDS (2%) and SDS (2%) in combination with β- ME (150 mM) at different temperatures
sec.p: For the studies, 5 μg of each protein was incubated in the presence of 2% SDS or 2% SDS in combination with β- ME (150 mM) at 30 ◦ C and 50 ◦ C for 3 min and quickly transferring the reaction mixture to ice-bath after the incubation. The residual activities of the enzymes were estimated by assaying enzyme with azocasein as substrate as explained earlier. Enzymes (Pc and PcB) in presence of 50 mM phosphate buffer pH 7.0 were kept as control.

sec.title: 5.4.3. In presence of GdnHCl (2–4 M) or GdnHCl (2–4 M) in combination with β- ME (150 mM) at different temperatures
sec.p: For the studies, 5 μg of each protein was incubated in the presence of GdnHCl (2, 3 and 4 M) or GdnHCl (2, 3 and 4 M) in combination with β- ME (150 mM) at 30 ◦ C, 50 ◦ C and 65 ◦ C for 3 min and quickly transferring the reaction mixture to ice-bath after the incubation. The residual activities of the enzymes were estimated by assaying enzyme with azocasein as substrate as explained earlier. The autocatalysis in these conditions was monitored by subjecting the proteins to SDS-PAGE in the presence of E-64 (0.1 mM). The reaction mixture was diluted 10- fold before addition of sample buffer in order to avoid precipitation of SDS in presence of high concentration of GdnHCl. Enzymes (Pc and PcB) in presence of 50 mM phosphate buffer pH 7.0 were kept as control.

sec.title: 5.4.4. Autocatalysis in presence of SDS-PAGE sample buffer components
sec.p: For this study, 5 μg of each protein (Pc and PcB) was incubated individually in presence of 50 mM Tris buffer pH 6.8, 2% SDS, 150 mM β- ME and in combination of 2% SDS and 150 mM β- ME for 3 min under boiling conditions. The autocatalysis in these conditions was then monitored by subjecting the proteins to SDS-PAGE in the presence of E-64 (0.1 mM).

The same study was also repeated by subjecting the enzymes to all the aforementioned conditions at different temperatures (30 ◦ C, 50 ◦ C, 60 ◦ C, 70 ◦ C, 75 ◦ C, 80 ◦ C and 85 ◦ C) to understand the effect of temperature on autocleavage of the enzymes thereon.

sec.title: 5.4.5. Kinetic stability of different proteases of C1 family in presence of
sec.p: β- ME

Papain (40 μg), Bromelain (100 μg), Pc (60 μg) and PcB (70 μg) were incubated at 50 ◦ C in 20 mM phosphate buffer pH 7.0 containing different concentrations of β- ME in the range of 10–400 mM with final volume 50 μL. The residual activities of the enzymes were determined at intervals up to 2 h and expressed as specific activities using 5 μL of the aliquot. The autocatalysis in these conditions at the end of 2 h was also monitored by subjecting the proteins to SDS-PAGE in the presence of E-64 (0.1 mM) using 10 μL of the aliquot.

sec.title: 5.5. Differential scanning fluorimetry
sec.p:
The experiment was carried out as described by (
). Pc and PcB were used at a final concentration of 26 μM and 16 μM, respectively, for this assay. SYPRO Orange dye was used at a final concentration of 20X for native protein and 10X for studying thermal denaturation in the presence of denaturant, GdnHCl. Thermal denaturation was carried out in following conditions: 1. Phosphate citrate buffer pH 7.0 (50 mM) in presence and absence of E-64 (0.1 mM). 2. Phosphate citrate buffer pH 7.0 (50 mM) containing activator (150 mM β- ME) and/or denaturant (GdnHCl, at concentration 2 M, 3 M and 4 M) in the presence or absence of E-64 (0.1 mM). All DSF experiments were carried out with Rotogen Q (Qiagen, Germany ). Each reaction sample was divided in to three 20 μL replicates. Sample solutions were dispensed into PCR tubes. Fluorescence intensity was measured via the HRM channel (Ex 460 nm and Em at 510 nm ) and temperature in the range pf 35–95 ◦ C was continuously increased at 0.1 ◦ C/s with holding time of 5 s at each temperature. The melting curves obtained were directly exported from the instrument, and then were analysed with Prism 7 (Graph-Pad Software Inc, USA ).

sec.title: 5.6. Homology modelling and Molecular dynamics simulations
